column17: on his passage to Ceylon. He served throughout the campaigns in Spain as a Captain of Light Infantry in the 51st regiment
column18: and behaved with great gallantry in the battle of the Pyrenees
column19: where being shot in the thigh he was sent home by the Medical Board
column20: and on his recovery was placed by the Duke of York on the Staff of the Army in the Adjutant-General's Department when the Duke of Wellington took the command in Flanders. He was in the battle of the 16th of June
column21: and afterwards on the 18th at the battle of Waterloo
column22: where his station placed him in the dangerous position of being attendant on the Duke
column23: around whom almost every officer was either killed or wounded. Amongst the rest this brave young man had his left arm carried off by a cannon-ball
column24: which passing along the other laid bare the whole of it
column25: by which he lost the use of two of his fingers
column26: but that arm was saved. When the cannon-shot had thrown him from his horse
column27: and as he lay bleeding upon the groun in this mangled condition
column28: the Prussian musketry and trumpets being heard at a distance
column29: he seized his hat with his remaining shattered arm. and waving it round him cheered his companions in the midst of the dying and the dead
column30: the Duke of Wellington being then close by him who desired he might carried to his tent. It must be some consolation to his afflicted family
column31: that he must have distinguished himself in the opinion of his great Commander
column32: as he was immediately recommended by him for the rank of Major
column34: and in a year afterwards to the rank of Lieutenant-Colonel
column35: with the appointment of Adjutant-General in Ceylon
column36: and if he had then fortunately sailed for India his life might probably have been saved ; but his disposition being as affectionate as it was animated
column37: he could not be persuaded to leave Mrs Erskine
column39: and remaining here during the winter
column43: laid too deep a hold on him to derive benefit from the voyage
column44: and he died on his passage to India. Colonel Erskine was only 25 years of age
